pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw: When breaking out this to a function like `check_is_close` you should just raise the `PriorSizeWarning` in there and try/catch here. The reason for this is for better contextual error messages. This error message in particular could be far more helpful. Getting an index printed out for some small downsampled resolution region is not at all. Perhaps showing which values summed to be >1 \(in this example\) would be better so at least a user can search for the particular offending prior combination.
content.html: When breaking out this to a function like check_is_close you should just raise the PriorSizeWarning in there and try/catch here. The reason for this is for better contextual error messages. This error message in particular could be far more helpful. Getting an index printed out for some small downsampled resolution region is not at all. Perhaps showing which values summed to be >1 (in this example) would be better so at least a user can search for the particular offending prior combination.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
There probably wasn’t enough clarity in the `check_is_close` initial discussion regarding on how roughly it should look. The objective was just to abstract the old `EPSILON` checks out into a function in case we want to change the exact behavior in the future \(using np.is\_close or some other threshold\). So I believe the function signature should look something like `check_is_close(value, reference)` or something along those lines where potentially the prior sum takes place outside the function before calling it \(from my understanding\) and `reference` in most cases would simply be called with a value of `1.0`.

The `start` parameter also seems out of place. I’m not even quite sure what it means but it looks like it’s strictly used for better error reporting. In this case, it would be better, as you have to raise the custom warning and have the caller use its context \(with `start`\) for a better error report.

Unit tests are welcome on this function.
content.html:
There probably wasn’t enough clarity in the check_is_close initial discussion regarding on how roughly it should look. The objective was just to abstract the old EPSILON checks out into a function in case we want to change the exact behavior in the future (using np.is_close or some other threshold). So I believe the function signature should look something like check_is_close(value, reference) or something along those lines where potentially the prior sum takes place outside the function before calling it (from my understanding) and reference in most cases would simply be called with a value of 1.0.

The start parameter also seems out of place. I’m not even quite sure what it means but it looks like it’s strictly used for better error reporting. In this case, it would be better, as you have to raise the custom warning and have the caller use its context (with start) for a better error report.

Unit tests are welcome on this function.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
I’ll add a reference to the function in case this is ever needed to check another number.

I’m not sure the advantage of summing the lines individually before sending it to check\_is\_close\(\). To do this we’d either need to explicitly sum before sending to the function or use it at a downstream location, `get_downsampled_virtual_evidence_data_and_presence` where they are already summed. Doing the latter would mean that we are no longer able to give the chromosomal indices which go over reference. 

You’re correct, the start parameter was me trying to make the error message more informative and allows us to give the exact chromosomal indices which are over reference. I’m not sure how you’d use context for this problem.
content.html:
I’ll add a reference to the function in case this is ever needed to check another number.

I’m not sure the advantage of summing the lines individually before sending it to check_is_close(). To do this we’d either need to explicitly sum before sending to the function or use it at a downstream location, get_downsampled_virtual_evidence_data_and_presence where they are already summed. Doing the latter would mean that we are no longer able to give the chromosomal indices which go over reference.

You’re correct, the start parameter was me trying to make the error message more informative and allows us to give the exact chromosomal indices which are over reference. I’m not sure how you’d use context for this problem.

content.raw: This is much better. However I think there’s still a bit of overengineering here. This is supposed to be a wrapper around effectively a `abs(reference - value) <= EPSILON` kind of deal. Ideally there should only be one return type \(a boolean\). Returning `True` if actually close enough and raise a warning otherwise \(from my understanding of Michael’s original request\). Outside this function, the callee should use the prior sums should be checked with something like `any` which you are doing here.
content.html: This is much better. However I think there’s still a bit of overengineering here. This is supposed to be a wrapper around effectively a abs(reference - value) <= EPSILON kind of deal. Ideally there should only be one return type (a boolean). Returning True if actually close enough and raise a warning otherwise (from my understanding of Michael’s original request). Outside this function, the callee should use the prior sums should be checked with something like any which you are doing here.

pullrequest.title: Implement virtual evidence for all segway tasks

content.raw:
You are doing something similar here and in `downsample_presence_array()`. This should be a new function, similar to:

```
from numpy import pad

def window_array(arr, stride):
    pad_length = len(arr) % stride
    arr_padded = pad(arr, (0, pad_length), constant_values=0)
    
    # first dimension inferred
    return arr_padded.reshape((-1, stride))
```

In `downsample_presence_array()` you can just call `.sum()` along the correct axis to do a fast sum.
content.html:
You are doing something similar here and in downsample_presence_array(). This should be a new function, similar to:

from numpy import pad

def window_array(arr, stride):
    pad_length = len(arr) % stride
    arr_padded = pad(arr, (0, pad_length), constant_values=0)

    # first dimension inferred
    return arr_padded.reshape((-1, stride))

In downsample_presence_array() you can just call .sum() along the correct axis to do a fast sum.
